President Confined To
Hospital Bed With
Bronchitis
Having suffered for about ten
days with an attack of bronchitis,
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, has been in the
Johns Hopkins Hospital since
last Tuesday. •
Dr. Ames is now recovering,
according to reports from his office, and is expected to leave the
hospital in about a week. The
meeting of the Trustees, scheduled for Monday, was postponed
because of the President's illness.

SIGN BALLOT AND DEPOSIT IN POST OFFICE.

NOTED ECONOMIST
VISITS THE HOPKINS

In order to reduce the individual
senior dues for members of the
sophomore and freshman classes,
the officers of these respective bodies met at a joint meeting and decided on a combined dance, and a
condensed banquet season, subject
to the approval of the class members at assembly Thursday.
The best manner of reducing or
even abolishing senior dues, it was
decided, is to build up the class
treasury as early as possible. This
is planned to be done by running a
dance, sponsored by both classes in
order to reduce the expenses for the
individual class. This will also allow a better orchestra and a bigger
and better affair. If approved by
the class members, this affair will be
the first of its kind in five years.

under a different consideration altogether. If the
NEWS-LETTER, Blue Jay, Hullabaloo, Barnstormers,
Musical Club, Debating Society, and Band do not get
financial support from the students, they cannot survive with any degree of effective existence. We will
concede that economies can be effected, and indeed
they have been to no small extent this year. This
means that the activities can get along on less and it
would indicate the possibility of a reduced fee. But
this idea of reducing the fee has been in prospect ever
since the 0. D. K.committee last Spring recommended
it, and it would have been in effect now, probably,
if the banks hadn't closed up with our funds.
In the light of these considerations activities men
can hardly be expected to vote for abolition. They
are willing to accept the burden of a lowered fee
("modification"), but can go no farther. There is
strong possibility that, if the fees are ever abolished,
the university will simply raise its tuition fees.
And that smacks of selling your horse to buy a
jackass.

President Confined To
Hospital Bed With
Bronchitis
Having suffered for about ten
days with an attack of bronchitis,
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, has been in the
Johns Hopkins Hospital since
last Tuesday. •
Dr. Ames is now recovering,
according to reports from his office, and is expected to leave the
hospital in about a week. The
meeting of the Trustees, scheduled for Monday, was postponed
because of the President's illness.

SIGN BALLOT AND DEPOSIT IN POST OFFICE.

NOTED ECONOMIST
VISITS THE HOPKINS

In order to reduce the individual
senior dues for members of the
sophomore and freshman classes,
the officers of these respective bodies met at a joint meeting and decided on a combined dance, and a
condensed banquet season, subject
to the approval of the class members at assembly Thursday.
The best manner of reducing or
even abolishing senior dues, it was
decided, is to build up the class
treasury as early as possible. This
is planned to be done by running a
dance, sponsored by both classes in
order to reduce the expenses for the
individual class. This will also allow a better orchestra and a bigger
and better affair. If approved by
the class members, this affair will be
the first of its kind in five years.

NEWS-LETTER, Blue Jay, Hullabaloo, Barnstormers,
Musical Club, Debating Society, and Band do not get
financial support from the students, they cannot survive with any degree of effective existence. We will
concede that economies can be effected, and indeed
they have been to no small extent this year. This
means that the activities can get along on less and it
would indicate the possibility of a reduced fee. But
this idea of reducing the fee has been in prospect ever
since the 0. D. K.committee last Spring recommended
it, and it would have been in effect now, probably,
if the banks hadn't closed up with our funds.
In the light of these considerations activities men
can hardly be expected to vote for abolition. They
are willing to accept the burden of a lowered fee
("modification"), but can go no farther. There is
strong possibility that, if the fees are ever abolished,
the university will simply raise its tuition fees.
And that smacks of selling your horse to buy a
jackass.

a fully packed cigarette. And remember,"It's
toasted"—for throat protection—for finer taste.
